see it says the Istrian hill towns although they just lie they lie just a short distance from inlainland from the busy Croat ccoastal resorts the hill towns of Istria offer a completely different experience even if you were staying by the sea in Porec Pula or Rovinj it's worth renting a car for the day and heading inland to the vineyards olive groves and old pubs this short easy circuit takes in two of the most dramatic hill towns though it can be extended to include others
is Motovun one of them? or Buzet? mm yeah Motovun cos it goes in a big circle
Motovun's the one on the hill isn't it?
yeah so we must live somewhere around here

begin in Pazin which can be reached on the fast road connecting Rijeka with Rovinj and Pula this small industrial town with a population of around ten thousand may not have immediate appeal but it is worth a flying visit the highlight is the castle first mentioned in nine nine hundred and eighty-three AD as a gift from emperor Otto the second of Hungary to the bishop of Porec the castle now and ethnographic museum
was that was that what actually really happened or is that just mythology?
it says the highlight is the castle and the castle was first mentioned in nine hundred and eighty-three AD as a gift from an emperor to the bishop of Porec
you didn't put up a sugar in there did you?
the castle now and ethnographic museum overlooks a great gorge known as Pazin's pit where the river Pazinicia swells after rain
let me get rid of the skin
do you want me to stir it?
why don't you ask for some hot milk to mix it with?
I'd use a spoon like you do tubby custard

alalthough he never visited Pazin the French novelist Jules Verne was inspired by the pit and the little river that disappears underground the hero of his novel Mathias Sandorf was imprisoned in the castle and escaped by swimming along the underground river to the sea leave Pazin by taking the main road through the middle of town in the direction of Rijeka and the Ucka Tunnel after two kilometres blah-di-blah-di-blah-di-blah it's just giving you directions the little village of Draguc little more than a single road of houses and a tall church perched on a cliff in the seventies and eighties this was known as the Istrian Hollywood as a number of films were shot here but these days the village is largely deserted
n does it not say which films were done?
probably won't know any of them will we?
probably be all like Istrian films you know like small

Buzet is the largest of the hill towns on a bluff a hundred and fifty-one metres above the River Mirna and still partly enclosed by its medieval walls and gates mm buzet has more recently become Istria's self-styled town of truffles and each attracts a large number of visitors who come here to taste and buy this expensive delicacy
